A polynomial with coefficients in a field or ring is defined as a formal sum $f=\sum_{j=0}^{n} a_{j} X^{j}$, where $a_{j}$ are the coefficients. This definition emphasizes that a polynomial is identified with the sequence of its coefficients.

An ideal \(\mathfrak{a}\) in a ring \(R\) is called reduced if \(\mathfrak{a} = \operatorname{rad} \mathfrak{a}\), where \(\operatorname{rad} \mathfrak{a}\) is the set of all elements \(a \in R\) such that there exists some \(n \in \mathbb{N}\) with \(a^{n} \in \mathfrak{a}\).

Explanation: The concept of a reduced ideal involves the notion of an ideal and the radical of an ideal in a ring. The definition of a reduced ideal states that an ideal \\(\textbackslash{}mathfrak{a}\\) in a ring \\textit{R}\\ is reduced if \\(\textbackslash{}mathfrak{a} = \textbackslash{}operatorname{rad} \textbackslash{}mathfrak{a}\\), where the radical of an ideal \\(\textbackslash{}operatorname{rad} \textbackslash{}mathfrak{a}\\) includes elements \\textit{a}\\ in \\textit{R}\\ such that \\textit{a}^{n}\\ is in \\(\textbackslash{}mathfrak{a}\\) for some \\textit{n}\\ in \\(\textbackslash{}mathbb{N}\\). This definition is self-contained within the context of ring theory and does not inherently require the concept of a polynomial. A polynomial is a formal sum of terms with coefficients and powers of a variable, typically used in algebraic contexts but not necessary for defining what an ideal or its radical is in ring theory.
